reviewText:
This is a game that's somewhat overlooked. With the number of games released it is no wonder sometimes really good games slip between the cracks and fail to get the attention they deserve.
It has tons of atmosphere in a snowy landscape where a bunch of people under your avatars leadership is struggling to survive a lawless environment filled with animals, bandits , slave traders and nature itself.
As you lead your group of people  you have to maintain a relationship with each, hear their stories and make decisions all the time on what to do or where to go. The plot has you trying to free some friends from slave traders and in your quest you have to constantly take care of the needs of your group  by hunting, scavenging, trading and talking to people.
The controls are flawless, (you can just point and click on the map to tell the group where to go and while moving you have to keep an eye out for sites to hunt or scavenge. Sometimes you have to fight and this means making choices on how to approach the fight in several stages and the fight resolves itself.
The drawings and the artwork is first class , the storytelling engaging and the gameplay varied enough to keep you going.  The music is atmospheric as it should be.
So, once again I am seriously amazed at this game not making a bigger splash than it did so far. For the price they ask it's guaranteed to make you very happy you bought this game.  9/10

Yeah, it's a bit buggy, but if you're a fan of old CRPGs, the gameplay will more than make up for that. ICY is somewhere between Fallout and Banner Saga in tone, and although the writing has a very translated feeling to it, the visuals that go along with that writing are magnificent and worth the price of admission.

$10 is not a bad buy if you *really* like this type of thing (text heavy, minimalist, stark, three hours long), but it's a $5 game at heart.

--

GRIPES: very short, way too easy on 'normal', stats don't seem to do anything, skills don't seem to do anything, the economy is laughably breakable in the first town, resource management is never a problem, game feels more like a prologue to a longer piece, with entire characters' extended backstories being cut, combat bugs itself into a simplified state, invisible inventory items, quests that dump you right back to the start for picking an unscripted choice, quest choices that are nonsensical or counter-intuitive, lynxes that turn into deer that turn back into lynxes, broken day/night system, dialog is sometimes very narmy.

PRAISE: beautiful visuals, you get to put together a huge party, surprisingly good freedom of choice in very limited ways, stark lovely setting, better ending than Mass Effect 3, terrifying string of choices involving a tree.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Definitely recommended if you enjoy the genre, despite a few bugs and poor translation.

I was tempted to purchase this from Splattercat's Let's Play on Youtube, and overall think the game was worth buying. The hand drawn art style is very well executed and the narrative is excellent. If you enjoy text based games, there's a lot of fun to be had here.

The RPG-esque character building system the game opens with is interesting, allowing you to allocate points into conversation based skills, or exploration and combat skills (to turn the game's RNG in your favour). I would like to see stronger influences in-game from how you allocate your stats however, as the difficulty on Story Mode made this seem slightly inconsequential. I went with a purely social build and din't have many issues with combat, especially since it's easy to balance out relatively quickly.

Although fun to play, the number of random events and outcomes need to be greatly expanded upon. A lot of looting events are constantly repeated and have mismatched outcomes (characters randomly falling off cliffs when looting a building, etc). You can also spoil the story if you decide to explore areas that you aren't being guided to by the quest system.

There's an interesting selection of loot in the game, but sadly you can only equip the player character and not your entire group. I'd appreciate being able to equip my spare weapons onto other party members, since it's unclear if they even effect your combat stats.

Dialogue wise, it would be nice to see some of the weird translations and syntax patched into more colloquial English. The story is excellent and poor translation can spoil the immersion.

Even though I'm being critical, I really enjoy the game overall and think a patch or two could make something good truly outstanding. Hopefully we see a few updates soon! I think some community involvement with the Devs would do a world of good.

Icy asks what you would do to survive and protect the ones you love. Leading a band of nomads across a frozen waste, you will constantly be faced with hard decisions. From choosing where you lead your family, what quests you take and even who lives and who dies. Icy can best be explained as a choose your own adventure style game. The gameplay itself is rather simplistic in nature with good art backgrounds and portraits, and plenty of written narrative. If you're not a fan of reading, might wanna pass. One of the highlights of Icy is it's replay, while the beginning usually starts the same, once you reach the open world you are given plenty of paths that are affected by your skills. Perhaps you choose to master stealth or be a deadly bowman. All of these will change the outcome of events and shape the story. In all if you're a fan of games like Richard & Alice, The Banner Saga, Icy has something to offer you with it's very mature story and deadly consequences themed gameplay. So stay warm and hold on to the ones you love because things are going to get a little Icy.

I found this game in its early development, when it got featured on Gamejolt. Trust me it had lots of bugs, not even a save system. And from the 2+ hours i played on this Steam version, it showed me that the developers do care (at least somewhat) about their game. Making improvements from save system and crashing issues to graphical changes and new characters or dialogue. And along with performace, the amazing artist has made more portraits and scenary, all of them extremely beautiful.

The story and RPG aspect is interesting, at least mostly enveloping and imersing you into the world you must now survive in. It gives plenty of atmosphere, a decent soundtrack, plenty of characters in your party with their own distinct personality and simple backstories, along with items and skills that will affect your combat and/or survivabilty. The choices of dialogue are easily understandable and rather straight forward, so no real problems there. Traveling around the wasteland is incredibly easy: easy to know where objectives are, where your parties is, what every object on the map is.

But thats about it for the game.

Performance is terrible, often taking a long time loading MORE PIECES OF TEXT. And thats coming from a computer with a 4.2GHZ processor. I can't see whats so hard about loading text or still images. Options are limited or bugged as well, not being able to turn down the Sound Effects so I may hear the quiet Music is a real pain in the butt seeing as to that should be expected from any game, as too online flash games have volume control. Even the option to turn the graphics from Fastest to Beautiful isn't saved after you quit the game. What graphics are even turned down? The resolution of images? If that is the case, then turning down resolution of a game based on still pictures and text would make the game way less beautiful and imersive. Why is there even graphical options? Its text and still images. And along with performance issues and low Options or features, is the noticible grammer errors, mispellings or, (what i presume to be) mistakes in the pictures, like just some weird details in it. Combat feels rather bare and strange honestly. I feel like I'm slaughtering doezens of Bandits or Raiders thanks to the special event after the main offensive, usually the special event tells of at least one man getting shot and killed or just killed in some other way. And their doesn't feel to be a ranking up in weapons of any sort, due to the fact you may seach a chest and find a rifle when most of your weapons are crude bows.

But I have ONE main problem with this game: detail.

This game does not feel like it provides enough detail for me to be completely imersed and excited about the story. Right now, I'm on a quest for revenge for some of the tribesman some mercanaries captured. The problem is I don't really care. I never really knew the people that were captured. All I really knew was that is was a mother and two children. I wasn't able to spend enough time to get to know them, but that's the main objective so far in the game, so I feel unmotivated to go hunting for them. Characters feel vague and shell-like, same about scenary. In other words, I feel like I'm missing that detail to paint the clear picture in my head, from both the landscapes and the dialogue.

However, even if all these things make the game look bad, trust me, it is anything but. I personally freaking love this game. It feels like it has a lot of charm and care put into it. Like the developers WANTED to make this game, not just for profit, but for the sake of making this game. It is their first game, so bugs, mistakes, or poor disign are expected. So I will be patiently waitng for updates that I know will happen to fix or improve this game. These developers feel like they have a lot of potential and I can't wait for more adventures, and I will most likely buy them the day they come out just like this game, and I would recommened anyone else to do the same.

And if Inner Void is reading this, I was guy who recommened names under portraits, and you said that you were going to do that. Why isn't that there? Like... the fuq? Whatever, love you guys. <3

Edit: I am glad they are actively patching the game. As of right now, I still do not recommend it. I will continue to update my review as they update their game.

Icy is a survival RPG in a frozen, post-apocalyptic world. You play as the leader of a nomadic tribe who has amnesia and make choices in a barren environment while balancing your needs, the group's needs, and the resources necessary to survive.

I originally backed this game on Indiegogo because it looked interesting and was only $5. Displaying gif's and art to promote the game, it seemed like it had promise. However, when I played the game, it was severely disappointing. The storyline is minimal and the character development is slight as well. I did not feel attached to any character even if they had a traumatic event happen to them. In addition, because the game relies mainly on text to further the storyline, I expected the game to have few errors in the writing. Although, it is just the opposite. In less than an hour, I found several spelling errors and repeats which detract from the overall atmosphere the games wishes to create. In fact, the writing is nothing special as well. It feels like an average high schooler wrote everything as the content was dry.

The quest in the beginning of the game wasn't very thought-out either. Rather than vary the requests that one receives, the quest-giver asks for the same items repeatedly. This detracts from the storyline as the place doesn't seem to be fully self-sufficient. Also, this makes it seem like a grind-fest to get currency (ammo) in the game and bored me even further.

Consequently, the skill/stat system and battle system are very much so intertwined. When one creates a character, they have the ability to choose between 3 main stats and 10 skills. (I just put points in pretty much everything like a jack-of-all-trades.) These skills typically determine the success of an action. It seemed very flawed because while I perked most of my skill points into less violent means such as sneaking and medicine, I did not feel like they may have helped me at all. There was no success chance or anything, just a simple pass or fail. The battle system had very little variety as well. When fighting a battle, I remember about 4 different scenarios -- most of which have slight variations in terms of choices one is allowed.

Lastly, the movement on the map isn't smooth or practical. There are certain landmarks on the map which allow the party to scavenge, hunt, or even proceed with a mission. In order to get to these landmarks, you click and your character will move. While moving, a figurine that represents your party just slides on a 2-D map. Although, there is no such thing as a stop. If you move, you will keep moving to that location even if it was an accident. In order to stop going there, you must click near yourself. This wastes valuable resources and time. In addition, if you do hit a landmark, it isn't very clear whether you actually hit it or not as the hitbox isn't accurate with the model. When doing one of the story quests, I was supposed to go to a church. I hit the edge of the church and nothing happened. I clicked a little closer and nothing happened. I had to go to the direct center before the event automatically played. I wish there was a Enter" button or something to make it a lot more clear that you can use the landmark.

In my opinion

reviewText: ICY is a game with an ambitious scope and limited resources to pursue it. Some of the menus are poorly designed, especially the trading menu. With the plethora of games that have used such a feature in the past it surprises me that the developers couldn't do a better job: it's really difficult to navigate. And important choices are an element that is well implemented throughout the entire game. I do feel like recommending this game, if only to support the effort this small team undertook. Just don't expect a masterpiece. I look forward to see more from this indie studio of developers!

The overall game is good, story arch and mechanics are well balanced and interesting to be stuck into it.

reviewText:
It's that time of the month when, bored by books and the act of reading, i find myself lusting for something good to play on my PC. So, scrolling my list of games, i find ICY, bought after its release.

I'm still playing, but i HAD the morale obligation to write this review.

ICY is a textual RPG set in a post-apocalyptic world, frozen more than Alaska during winter, but with more wolves and less freedom (Thank you, Obama). It's a cruel world, where the few survivors find themselves fighting for their lives day after day, against beasts, and infection, and lack of resources (food, combustile etc...). You're one of the survivors in this world, and the game start when you and one of the most experience guy of your tribe are hunting a deer. And since the start you can see the core of the game: strong writing, capable of describe the action without boring too much with WoT full of philosophycal thoughts on how we're hunting and not buying a mc Bacon for 3$, DAMN YOU HUMANITY, etc.
With the aid of beatiful artwork, ALL the action is put on screen with taste: taste for the story, for the setting, and with respect for the people playing the game.

The more you play, the more you want to play. All the companions on your party have a story, their ideas, their personality, that, like in all the good story, you're going to discover with your interactions with the world.

For 12,99 € (it's 6,99€ now with the steam sales), you can have a beatiful, little pearl, that will full around 4-5 hours of your life (i'm pretty sure my run is gonna take more, i love to procrastinate). And, if you are a RPG lover, you will find everything you need here: choices, consequences, skill check. All the package.
Stop playing Bethesda's Fallout. Buy ICY.

Fun for a few hours but lacks depth and didn't get me hooked or invested. It's like a less complex version of This War of Mine.

Conclusion:

reviewText:
TL;DR: If you dislike Visual novels, find another game. If you like visual novels, look up a Let's Play and see if you'll like this game.

Quick note: I really only talked about the meat of the game, any minor thing is generally ignored to make sure you understand what this game is. Visual novels aren't my style, hence why I'm not reccomending this game. If you like them, consider reading this; if you don't, then you've got your answer to whether or not you should buy this game.

ICY is a great example of a visual novel type game with an RPG element. The story gives off a TellTale Walking Dead feel to it. There is a real sense of desperation and you can really feel the atmosphere. I've only played this game a short while, but I got the general story down. The characters are sometimes hard to connect with, it seems like they never feel uncertain. It's black and white with them (a good example of this is about 5 minutes into the game before you sleep for the first time).

The main plot seems to be centered around getting...somewhere. The biggest problem I have with the game is the backstory to your character, as in, there isn't one. You have amnesia and you're essentially thrown into the middle of a family that, although your character is comfortable with, you have no idea who they are. This does not help when you're trying to get an understanding of how these characters feel. Let me recap really quick, you get no backstory expect that you were found and taken in by some people who became your family. That just isn't helpful!

Even if the backstory seems shallow, it does seem to pickup later on. The only issue with that is by the time it does, you're probably playing something else or already got bored of the game. That's what happened to me atleast.

The gameplay is alright. Like I said, I got bored of the game so I didn't expierience too much. The gameplay comes down to going into woods/forests and hunting or (I assume) find material. You can also scavange abadoned towns to find any material you need, if you can find it, that is.

Combat is one thing I didn't get into, let me explain. At the start of the game, you're allow to change/choose stats for your character. I put a lot into speechcraft and stealth, only to have the game throw me straight into combat within 15 minutes. Albiet, it's related to the story, but it isn't a good transition to get the story started. It feels a little clunky and cheaped out, and that's about the meat of the game.

There isn't much more to say. Dialogue choices seem like they don't really matter because it's either the story progresses or it doesn't. There isn't any in-between to that. For what ICY tries to do, it does it well, but not well enough. The transition from RPG to Novel to RPG just doesn't feel right, or I couldn't get into it atleast.

My final reccomendation for this game is: If you like Indie RPG's and/or visual novels, then check it out. If you don't like either, or just visiual novels in general; then keep moving. I'd highly request a demo for this game just to see if people can see if they'd like to purchase it.
